title: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
scope: ** Acute evaluation and secondary prevention after transient ischemic attack in adults. Covers risk stratification (ABCD2), urgent workup (MRI with DWI, vascular imaging, cardiac evaluation), dual antiplatelet therapy initiation, and rapid secondary prevention. TIA is a medical emergency — 90-day stroke risk is 10-15% without intervention, highest in first 48h. Excludes completed ischemic stroke (see Acute Ischemic Stroke template), hemorrhagic stroke, and TIA mimics.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia mimics TIA; must rule out immediately
Thrombocytosis or thrombocytopenia; polycythemia; anemia; infection
Electrolytes; renal function for contrast; hepatic function

Extended Workup.rationale: Vasculitis screen; giant cell arteritis (age >50 with TIA); inflammatory markers
Elevated homocysteine as independent stroke risk factor

Rare/Specialized.item: Hypercoagulable panel (Protein C, S, antithrombin III, Factor V Leiden, prothrombin gene mutation)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Young patient (<50); cryptogenic TIA; personal/family history of thrombosis

Rare/Specialized.item: Antiphospholipid antibodies (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, β2-glycoprotein I)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Young TIA; recurrent TIA; systemic lupus; recurrent pregnancy loss
Sickle cell disease (young patients, African descent)
Independent cardiovascular risk factor; elevated in 20% of population

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h (ideally <6h). DWI-positive in 30-50% of clinical TIA — these patients are at HIGHEST stroke risk and may be reclassified as minor stroke
Essential/First-line.target: DWI restriction = acute ischemia (even if symptoms resolved, this upgrades risk and may change to minor stroke diagnosis); FLAIR changes; prior infarcts

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate (if MRI unavailable or contraindicated); excludes hemorrhage and mass
Essential/First-line.target: No hemorrhage; no mass; may show old infarcts

Essential/First-line.item: CTA head and neck (OR MRA head and neck)
Essential/First-line.timing: With initial imaging or within 24h. Evaluates extracranial AND intracranial vessels
Essential/First-line.target: Carotid stenosis (≥50% NASCET); intracranial stenosis; vertebral stenosis; dissection
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy; renal impairment (for CTA). MRA: pacemaker

Essential/First-line.target: Atrial fibrillation (detected in 5-10% on initial ECG); atrial flutter; acute MI; LVH; old infarct
Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (detected in additional 5-7% with monitoring)

Extended.target: LV thrombus; PFO; valvular disease; cardiomyopathy; akinetic segments

Extended.timing: If TTE nondiagnostic; cryptogenic TIA; young patient
Extended.target: PFO with right-to-left shunt; atrial septal aneurysm; LAA thrombus; aortic arch atheroma (≥4mm)

Extended.timing: Within 24h (may be obtained instead of or in addition to CTA/MRA)
Extended.target: Carotid stenosis ≥50%; plaque characterization; hemodynamic significance

Extended.item: Extended cardiac monitoring (Holter 30-day or implantable loop recorder)
Extended.timing: Arrange before discharge; especially if cryptogenic TIA
Extended.target: Paroxysmal AF (detected in 12-30% with prolonged monitoring in cryptogenic cases)

Extended.timing: If PFO evaluation needed (alternative to TEE bubble); also for intracranial stenosis and microembolic signals
Extended.target: Right-to-left shunt; intracranial stenosis; microembolic signals

Extended.timing: If diagnosis uncertain; evaluate for persistent hypoperfusion despite symptom resolution
Extended.target: Perfusion deficits suggesting ongoing ischemic risk

Rare/Specialized.timing: If intracranial stenosis suspected on CTA/MRA; vasculitis workup; Moyamoya
Rare/Specialized.target: Beading (vasculitis); intimal flap (dissection); Moyamoya collaterals; intracranial stenosis quantification
Vessel wall enhancement (active inflammation, unstable plaque)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If cervical dissection suspected (neck pain, Horner syndrome, young patient)

dosing.instructions: 325 mg PO loading dose immediately upon TIA diagnosis (give in ED). Do NOT delay antiplatelet therapy

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active GI bleed; true aspirin allergy; thrombocytopenia <50K

doseOptions.orderSentence: Clopidogrel (loading dose for DAPT) 300 mg PO

dosing.instructions: 300 mg PO loading dose (give with aspirin for DAPT). DAPT is standard for high-risk TIA (ABCD2 ≥4) or minor stroke per CHANCE and POINT trials
dosing.orderSentence: Clopidogrel (loading dose for DAPT) 300 mg PO

Acute/Emergent.item: Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT maintenance): Aspirin + Clopidogrel

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT maintenance): Aspirin + Clopidogrel 81 mg -

dosing.instructions: Aspirin 81 mg daily + Clopidogrel 75 mg daily x 21 days (CHANCE protocol) or x 90 days (POINT protocol — higher bleeding risk with longer duration). Then transition to single antiplatelet (typically clopidogrel 75 mg or aspirin 81 mg monotherapy)
dosing.orderSentence: Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT maintenance): Aspirin + Clopidogrel 81 mg -

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dual antiplatelet therapy (alternative): Aspirin + Ticagrelor 81 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Aspirin 81 mg daily + Ticagrelor 90 mg BID x 30 days (THALES trial; for minor stroke NIHSS ≤5). Then single antiplatelet
dosing.orderSentence: Dual antiplatelet therapy (alternative): Aspirin + Ticagrelor 81 mg PO

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Intracranial hemorrhage history; high bleeding risk; hepatic impairment
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Bleeding; dyspnea (common side effect); avoid strong CYP3A4 inhibitors

dosing.instructions: Atorvastatin 80 mg PO daily (or Rosuvastatin 20-40 mg). Start immediately regardless of baseline LDL

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: LFTs at 12 weeks; lipid panel at 4-12 weeks; CK if myalgia

dosing.instructions: If SBP >220 or DBP >120 in ED: lower gently (15-25% in first 24h). If lower BP levels: permissive hypertension in first 24-48h unless end-organ damage. Avoid precipitous drops

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Carotid stenosis with hemodynamic TIA: do NOT aggressively lower BP (may worsen symptoms)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Neuro checks with each change; BP q1h acutely

dosing.instructions: Target BP <130/80 mmHg. Start/restart 24-48h after TIA once stable. Agent choice per comorbidities: ACE-I/ARB first-line. Consider: Lisinopril 10-20 mg daily, Amlodipine 5-10 mg, Losartan 50-100 mg, Chlorthalidone 12.5-25 mg

Secondary Prevention (Initiate Urgently).monitoring: Home BP monitoring; Cr and K+ at 1-2 weeks

dosing.instructions: Start DOAC within 1-3 days for TIA (can start earlier than stroke). Preferred: Apixaban 5 mg BID (2.5 mg BID if criteria met). Alternative: Rivaroxaban 20 mg daily; Dabigatran 150 mg BID. Discontinue antiplatelet when anticoagulant started (do NOT combine long-term unless specific indication)

Secondary Prevention (Initiate Urgently).contraindications: Active bleeding; mechanical valve (use warfarin); severe renal impairment
Secondary Prevention (Initiate Urgently).monitoring: Renal function q6-12 months; bleeding signs

dosing.instructions: For symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥50% (NASCET criteria); ideally performed within 2 weeks of TIA (maximum benefit). NNT = 6 for 70-99% stenosis; NNT = 22 for 50-69% stenosis

Secondary Prevention (Initiate Urgently).contraindications: Near-occlusion (controversial); life expectancy <5 years; severe cardiac comorbidity
Secondary Prevention (Initiate Urgently).monitoring: Post-op: BP monitoring; neuro checks q1h x 24h; wound hematoma; cranial nerve injury

dosing.instructions: Alternative to CEA if: high surgical risk, prior neck radiation, prior CEA with restenosis, surgically inaccessible. Requires DAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel) post-stenting
dosing.orderSentence: Carotid artery stenting (CAS) - Endovascular - see dosing

Secondary Prevention (Initiate Urgently).contraindications: Severe aortic arch tortuosity; fresh thrombus
Secondary Prevention (Initiate Urgently).monitoring: Post-procedure: BP management; neuro checks; DAPT compliance; restenosis surveillance

dosing.instructions: For cryptogenic TIA/stroke age 18-60 with PFO and right-to-left shunt. Reduces recurrent stroke vs medical therapy alone (CLOSE, RESPECT, REDUCE trials). Requires 3-6 months DAPT then aspirin indefinitely
10 mg PO daily; add if LDL not at goal on max statin

doseOptions.orderSentence: PCSK9 inhibitor (evolocumab or alirocumab) 140 mg SC

dosing.instructions: Evolocumab 140 mg SC q2 weeks or 420 mg monthly; if LDL not at goal on statin + ezetimibe
dosing.orderSentence: PCSK9 inhibitor (evolocumab or alirocumab) 140 mg SC

Secondary Prevention (Initiate Urgently).contraindications: Lipid panel q4-12 weeks; injection site

dosing.instructions: Target HbA1c <7% (individualized); GLP-1 agonists and SGLT2 inhibitors have cardiovascular benefit
Warfarin to target INR 2.5-3.5; bridge with heparin
Aspirin 325 mg + clopidogrel 75 mg daily x 90 days; then single antiplatelet + aggressive risk factor management
Antiplatelet or anticoagulation (both equally effective per CADISS trial); typically 3-6 months

Medications for Specific Etiologies.indication: Residual inflammatory risk (LoDoCo2 / COLCOT trials support in ACS — emerging data for stroke prevention)

Referrals & Consults.indication: All TIA patients; risk stratification; workup direction; secondary prevention
Symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥50% for CEA; ideally within 2 weeks
Carotid stenting; intracranial stenosis management; PFO closure referral
Newly detected AF; PFO evaluation; anticoagulation management; cardiac optimization
Extended cardiac monitoring arrangement; AF management
Risk factor management; medication titration; chronic disease management

Patient Instructions.item: TIA is a WARNING — risk of full stroke is HIGHEST in first 48h; take this very seriously
Call 911 IMMEDIATELY if any symptom recurs: sudden weakness, numbness, speech difficulty, vision changes, severe headache, loss of balance (F.A.S.T.)
Take all medications EXACTLY as prescribed; do NOT stop aspirin, clopidogrel, or statin without medical guidance
Do NOT drive for at least 2 weeks (state laws vary; some require neurologist clearance)
Return for follow-up within 1-2 weeks with neurology; primary care within 2-4 weeks
Blood pressure monitoring at home daily; keep log; target per physician guidance (<130/80)
Report any bleeding (bruising, blood in stool/urine, nosebleed) while on DAPT
Carry updated medication list at all times
Notify all providers of TIA history (dental, surgical, emergency)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise: 40 min moderate intensity, 3-4 days/week (after medical clearance)
Alcohol limitation: ≤1 drink/day women, ≤2 drinks/day men

differential.features: Gradual onset ("marching" symptoms over minutes); visual aura (scintillating scotoma); headache follows; younger; history of migraine
differential.tests: Normal MRI DWI; clinical history; gradual onset differentiates from sudden TIA

differential.features: Witnessed seizure; post-ictal confusion; resolves in hours; focal weakness post-seizure
differential.tests: EEG; MRI DWI negative; clinical history

differential.features: Glucose <60; diaphoresis; tremor; confusion; resolves with glucose
Isolated vertigo without other neurologic deficits; positive HINTS (peripheral pattern); nystagmus characteristics
differential.tests: HINTS exam; MRI DWI negative; normal CTA

differential.features: Young patient; symptoms disseminated in space and time; prior episodes; weeks duration
Subacute progressive symptoms; headache; may have transient symptoms from seizure or compression
Non-anatomic deficit distribution; Hoover sign; give-way weakness; psychological stressor
differential.tests: Normal MRI; normal vascular imaging; clinical exam

differential.features: Loss of consciousness; lightheadedness; no focal neurologic deficit
differential.tests: Orthostatic vitals; ECG; echo; tilt table

differential.features: Isolated sudden hearing loss + vertigo (AICA territory); may be a TIA equivalent
differential.tests: Audiometry (sensorineural hearing loss); MRI DWI (may show pontine or cerebellar infarct)

differential.features: Fluctuating symptoms; trauma history or anticoagulation; subacute
Isolated anterograde amnesia lasting hours; no motor or speech deficit; age >50; benign
differential.tests: Clinical presentation; MRI DWI (may show small hippocampal DWI lesions)

differential.features: Bilateral, non-focal; confusion predominant; abnormal labs

evidence.recommendation: DAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel 21 days) for minor stroke / high-risk TIA
DAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel 90 days) for minor stroke / high-risk TIA
evidence.source: [POINT trial (Johnston et al. NEJM 2018)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29766750/); higher ICH risk than 21 days

evidence.recommendation: Aspirin + ticagrelor x 30 days for minor stroke (NIHSS ≤5)
High-intensity statin for TIA secondary prevention
CEA within 2 weeks for symptomatic stenosis ≥50%
evidence.source: [NASCET (NEJM 1991)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1852179/); ECST; [Rothwell et al. (Lancet 2004)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15043958/) — maximum benefit if performed within 2 weeks

evidence.recommendation: DOACs preferred over warfarin for AF-related TIA/stroke
Extended cardiac monitoring for cryptogenic TIA
evidence.source: [CRYSTAL-AF (Sanna et al. NEJM 2014)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24963567/); [EMBRACE (Gladstone et al. NEJM 2014)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24963566/)

evidence.recommendation: PFO closure for cryptogenic stroke/TIA age 18-60
MRI DWI within 24h (DWI+ = higher stroke risk)

evidence.source: [Johnston et al. (Lancet 2007)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17227200/); useful but imperfect; imaging adds value

evidence.recommendation: Rapid TIA evaluation reduces 90-day stroke risk
evidence.source: [EXPRESS trial (Rothwell et al. Lancet 2007)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17928046/); [SOS-TIA (Lavallée et al. Lancet Neurol 2007)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17928270/)

evidence.recommendation: Medical therapy superior to stenting for intracranial stenosis

monitoring.frequency: q1h x 6h, then q4h in hospital; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: If symptoms recur: STAT MRI DWI; may need admission; upgrade to stroke protocol if persistent >24h or DWI+

monitoring.frequency: q1h x 6h in ED; q4h in hospital; daily at home
monitoring.action: Antihypertensive titration; avoid SBP <100 if carotid stenosis
If AF detected: anticoagulation; discontinue antiplatelet

monitoring.frequency: q6h in hospital; HbA1c at follow-up
Baseline; repeat at 4-12 weeks on statin
monitoring.action: Intensify statin; add ezetimibe or PCSK9i
≥4: admit or rapid TIA clinic within 24h; <4: may discharge with 24-48h follow-up if imaging complete

monitoring.frequency: After CEA/CAS: duplex at 1 month, 6 months, then annually

disposition.criteria: ABCD2 ≥4; crescendo TIA (recurrent within 24h); large vessel stenosis identified; atrial fibrillation detected; DWI-positive on MRI; incomplete workup that cannot be completed within 24h as outpatient
ABCD2 <4; symptoms fully resolved; no large vessel disease on imaging; no AF on ECG; MRI/CTA completed and negative; reliable follow-up; medications started
Low risk (ABCD2 0-3); all imaging completed and normal (MRI DWI negative, CTA normal, ECG sinus); medications started; reliable patient; follow-up within 24-48h guaranteed
Rarely needed; consider if hemodynamic TIA with critical stenosis; malignant hypertension; crescendo TIA progressing to stroke
If vascular imaging, MRI, or neurology consultation not available within 24h
